column4: ey, i got a amd64 cpu, is it just me, or is the repository not as huge, as with a normal 32 bit cpu - course with the breezy 64bit
when dapper comes out, what is the bennefit of installing the 64bit version, and not the 32bit, when i have to hack around alot with the 64bit
you don't, really, unless you're in desperate need of flash and/or wmv9
well, i do like flash, and use it on the web, and in my work and wmv9 too i spose
how about the speed of the computer, how much do i loose by using the 32bit version?
then you can either have a 32bit chroot, 32bit install, or a BiArch supporting distro :P
no idea of percentages, but if you're only using 32bit libs then there's really not much difference to having had a 32-bit processor
i think i have the 32bit firefox
suffice it to say I think it's certainly worth it :P
huh?
not on your amd64 ubuntu, unless it's in chroot
dunno :p but i think maybe most of my libs and apps are 32bit
maybe not then :p
if you had a 32bit install they would be
i have a 64bit install
so a 32bit install would work just as good then? well, i wouldnt feel the different?
obviously not. You wouldn't really be using the fact that it's a *64-bit processor*
but i dont really *need* 64bit on my workstation?
it can run a 32bit installation just fine, yes. It just wouldn't get all the advantages of a 64bit install
but theres still disadvantages i spose, when i need everyday stuff like flash, and i had some problems with firefox in the beginning
yes, on a pure ubuntu 64bint installation, there's no flash. Ubuntu isn't BiArch
yeah... but what are the advantages then?
